fields.description:
When watching a complete repository I want to have the ability to add exclude path/s.
Any commits in these exclude path/s will *not* result in a watch notification.

The obvious workaround is to not add a watch notification to the complete repository, but only to the subdirs you're interested in.
However, any newly added subdirs in the repository will then have to be added manually, which you likely miss/forget.
fields.summary: Ability to add exclude paths to watcher notifications

fields.description:
Show _Commit Graph_ and switch _Highlight_ from _Lineage_ to _Reviewed Changesets_.
A spinner is shown and the operation never completes.

Reproduced in several browsers/OSes.
Firefox reports:
{noformat}
Error: syntax error
Source File: http://localhost:8060/static/ls7qtt/concat.visualisation.04080093876f3999b26578b915adecf7.cache.js
Line: 2677
Source Code:
<!DOCTYPE html>

Error: no element found
Source File: http://localhost:8060/fe/saveBranchSet.do
Line: 1
{noformat}
fields.summary: Commit Graph / Highlight Reviewed Changesets: Operation never completes when api disabled

fields.description:
I have recently upgraded to Jira 4.4.1 and Fisheye 2.7.4 to make use of the Smart Commits functionality among other things.  I have it mostly working except that it does not populate the work log description on commit.  I can use the #comment without a problem and the #time command creates a new work log with the correct time value, but never populates the work log description.

Here is an example of a commit message: "CAPT-35 #time 15m Removed unnecessary fieldset from report view".  The new work log entry is created for 15 minutes of time for the issue CAPT-35, but the text that proceeds '15m' is not applied.  See attached.

Is this something I may have done incorrectly during the upgrade?
fields.summary: Work Log Description Not Populated with Smart Commit

fields.description:
The width of the swimlanes is adjusted automatically, depending on the number of lines that needs to be drawn in the lane.
If you have branches with names like {{release-branch-x}} and {{release-branch-y}}, and the swimlanes are small, you end up with ambiguous swimlane names at the top as they are cut off.
If you hover over them the full name is shown, but that's temporarily.
Would like to have an option to either manually resize the swimlane widths, and/or to make the lanes as wide as their branchname.
fields.summary: Add option to resize Commit Graph swimlane width

fields.description: For Subversion, paths under tag directories are displayed as greyed out items in the file tree, just like deleted files and empty directories.
fields.summary: SVN: Paths under tag directories are displayed as deleted / empty directories (greyed out)
Batched AUI javascript in FE 2.7.0-M5-r34ff301a6390 does not correspond with the bundled AUI version

fields.description:
When you select Source > All Repositories the list can be incredibly long. We for example have about 80 repositories. It would be very helpful to be able to filter that list down to a more manageable list.

If you go into administration and look at the repository list, there is a "Filter Repositories" option. Ideal this same field/feature would be available in the non-admin All Repositories list.
fields.summary: Allow Filtering "All Repositores" List
Repository path, includes, excludes and hidden directories should be copied to newly created forks

fields.description: When 'Store diffs' is turned off, FishEye still indexes the diffs for the initial import of a subversion repository.
fields.summary: 'Store diffs' setting is not respected for initial imports of SVN repositories
Outdated document for associating groups with repositories

fields.description:
The 'watches' feature of FishEye could use more highlighting -- users have to discover for themselves that they can watch the results of a filtered activity stream, and not just the activity stream on the dashboard.

The two pages on Watches come at the feature from the [admin angle|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/Watches] and the [user profile|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/Changing+your+User+Profile#ChangingyourUserProfile-watches], but may be helpful to add a page under [Using the FishEye Screens|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/Using+the+FishEye+Screens].
fields.summary: Elaborate on how to set watches on filter views

fields.description:
The my.atlassian generated a license with "<" and ">" characters and FishEye doesn't recognize the license:

After pasting this licenses into config.xml file Crucible doesn't start because of error:
2011-09-26 13:00:43,492 ERROR - Problem with config file: org.apache.xmlbeans.XmlException: error: Unexpected character encountered (lex state 8): '<'
fields.summary: FishEye doesn't start after editing config.xml by hand leaves it containing invalid XML

fields.description:
Tested with a Perforce repo, but I think this bug applies to all repo types.
When you change the Block Size of the repository, only a restart is needed to have FishEye pick up the changed setting.
Instead it shows a popup with the text
{noformat}
A reindex and restart required
A configuration change was made which requires a reindex and restart of the repository.
{noformat}
fields.summary: Changing Block Size triggers a reindex + restart, while only a restart is needed

fields.description:
Currently, user is not sure if READ-COMMITED isolation should be configure to FishEye database. It would be good if we could confirm on this matter and update the following documentation:
* http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/Migrating+to+MySQL+Enterprise+Server
fields.summary: Confirmatin on READ-COMMITED isolation level in FishEye database and update the database page

fields.description:
In some projects there are files that can get added that add to the line count of the project but do not truly portray the commited line count that has been coded.  As an example many .NET assemblies have XML files along with them that can artificially inflate (to sometimes excessive degrees, with hundreds of thousands of lines) the line code count.  Other files, such as .ai (Adobe Illustrator files) have no immediately visible word count but Fisheye parses them as lines, and that can inflate the count as well.  In the case of .ai files a folder of 280 or so bumped a line count from 300k lines to 10.8 million lines.

To rectify this it would be nice if a list of folders and/or a list of filetypes could be added to an "exclusion" or "inclusion" list for the line count.  This would allow a more accurate representation of what is held within the repositories for administrators and coders to use.
fields.summary: Add filter to total line counts that allows folder removal/exclusion and/or filetype inclusion/exclusion

fields.summary: Error upon exceeding license limit with Crowd user management

fields.description:
Chris points out that in trying to make email subjects more detailed, we clutter up his inbox because the different emails don't thread together (valid point).
!https://img.skitch.com/20110915-kndpcyjftk62wchw93jq51kfjc.png|thumbnail=true!
!https://img.skitch.com/20110915-tk5bfka1ats9c92ntk3gqhfwne.png!

Perhaps we should simplify review titles down to "{{\[Crucible\] REVIEW-KEY: Review Title}}"  no matter what type of email it is?
That would mean the different emails could be lumped into a single thread per review and not clutter an inbox.

I support this idea.
fields.summary: Group Crucible email threads by review

fields.description:
Customer reported:

Under some circumstances (haven't been able to pinpoint exactly, but it always occurs with a folder on one repository)

(You can access this folder using: http://www.bubblestuff.com:8060/jira/source/browse/HP/Emulators/emu48/trunk/EMU48.C)

Enter the HP repository and have selected a file. You are looking at the revisions screen.
In the tag selector select: emu48-1.44 tag (or any tag for the emu48 project)

You now see the revisions of the file for that particular tag.
Now click on "trunk" on the left of the tag name.

You then get a red screen with:
{noformat}
Your request was unable to be processed
javax.servlet.jsp.JspException - javax.el.PropertyNotFoundException: The class 'com.cenqua.fisheye.Path' does not have the property 'encodedUrl'.

javax.el.PropertyNotFoundException: The class 'com.cenqua.fisheye.Path' does not have the property 'encodedUrl'.
The class 'com.cenqua.fisheye.Path' does not have the property 'encodedUrl'.

You are running release CR2.7.2 FE2.7.2 (20110919054222 2011-09-19), please report your release number when reporting bugs.
{noformat}

You can select any tags, just not trunk

-----
(i) Please note that the mentioned URL is normally not publicly accessible.
Customer kindly opened it up to assist in solving this issue, but it will be closed up again in the future.

I reproduced this on OSX 10.7.1 with
- Chrome 14.0.835.186
- Opera 11.51
- Firefox 6.02
- Safari 5.1 (7534.48.3)

fields.description: FishEye should support referencing of a Mercurial changeset via its revision number, as well as by the changeset hash.

fields.description: With eclipse now providing full git support in their teaming projects, we'd like to use fisheye as our private git repository (public repos like github are not an option). Eclipse is integrating ALM feature mylyn and code review(gerrit) and it would be great to also get these working with the Jira, fisheye, crucible product set.

Please see the images attached for reference.

fields.description:
http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/SVN+Tag+and+Branch+Structure states
bq. You can add as many rules as you need. For any given file, the first rule that matches is used.

The developers told me that the branch name is inferred by going through the branch rules in the order they are defined in config.xml, then for all those matches, it picks up the 'best' match (which is the one with the smallest logical tail).

These statements contradict each other.
If the developers are correct then the docs need to be modified.
fields.summary: How are multiple branch rules interpreted?
Make chageset view configurable to be able to select the total number of diffs that can be loaded on a single page.
Allow non-administrative users to create managed repositories

fields.description:

fields.summary: Security warning when loading review on IE

fields.description:
There's a [bug in egit|https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=357719] that causes egit to fail to clone repositories if the server returns multiple WWW-Authenticate headers (which Fisheye does, as we support multiple authentication methods). 

As a workaround, we should lock the servlet that serves Git down to only support basic auth.
fields.summary: Eclipse Git integration (egit) fails to clone from managed Git repository

fields.description:
The atlassian-process-utils libary sets a default timeout of 1min, if it is not specified by the internal caller.

For Git repository management, this results in forcing the {{git-http-backend}} to timeout after that time (1min).

Change it to a large value, 1 hour, as the process is synchronous with the user + make it configurable by a system property in FishEye: {{fisheye.git.http-backend-timeout}}.
fields.summary: Augment the git-http-backend from 1min to 1hour

fields.summary: Trailing forward-slash in repository Location for managed repositories on Windows

fields.description:
We have a large team & our adoption of Fisheye is being hindered by the fact every time someone wants to add their repository to Fisheye one of ou admins has to do it.

We currently have a bunch of scripts that are part of our toolchain, one of which we use to clone existing git repos, I'd like to be able to have the fisheye repository created at the same time.

I've seen the new git clone features in the latest version of Fisheye, if this could be added to the API that would be good.
fields.summary: Extend the REST API to include editing repositories

fields.description:
JIRA issue screen, Source tab.
When there's an associated checkin, the {{Create crucible review}} link is shown.
Trying to open {{Create crucible review}} in a new browser tab or window, a duplicate of the issue screen is shown instead.

JIRA 4.3 with bundled FishEye plugin 3.1.2.
Reproduced with Opera 11.01, Chrome 10.0.648.151, FireFox 4.0, and Safari 5.0.4 (all on OS X).
fields.summary: Opening "Create crucible review" in a new browser tab or window opens a duplicate of the issue screen instead

fields.description:
[FishEye's Supported Platforms|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/Supported+Platforms] state that we don't support Mercurial 1.9 yet, but the issue it links to says it was added in 2.6.2.

Can we include Mercurial in the Dragon Slayer instructions? [Dragons Stage 4 - Install FishEye and Crucible, Step 1. Install Mercurial|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/ATLAS/Dragons+Stage+4+-+Install+FishEye+and+Crucible#DragonsStage4-InstallFishEyeandCrucible-Step1InstallMercurial]
fields.summary: Update supported platforms - we now support Mercurial 1.9

fields.description: The [Enabling Repository Management in FishEye|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE026/Enabling+Repository+Management+in+FishEye] isn't applicable for FishEye 2.6, and still references the EAP. Can it just be removed from the 2.6 space now that it has a home in the 2.7 space?
fields.summary: Remove 'Enabling Repository Management' document from the 2.6 space

fields.description: [What are the Starter License restrictions?|http://confluence.atlassian.com/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=203391708] should include [Git or Hg Repository exceeds number of allowed Committers|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHKB/Git+or+Hg+Repository+exceeds+number+of+allowed+Committers] in its FAQ, or as a section, to help this solution be more discoverable.
fields.summary: Add Git/Hg username inconsistency exceeding 10 committer limit help to Starter License Restriction page
Upgrade to Crowd 2.1+ and migrate to REST api

fields.description:
Since FishEye/Crucible 2.6, FishEye has switched from Crowd's SOAP API to its REST API (see FE-3705). This effectively makes FishEye only compatible with Crowd 2.1+ (see http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWDDEV/Crowd+REST+APIs for more info).

However the compatibility was not documented:
* https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/6484/fisheye-2-6-x-and-crowd-2-0-2
* http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/JIRA+and+Crowd+Authentication?focusedCommentId=246481449#comment-246481449
fields.summary: FishEye 2.6/2.7 are not compatible with any version of Crowd inferior to 2.1, but this is not documented

fields.description: I was able to work around this by clicking to get a trial license and copy / pasting the server id it put in the form to submit for a trial.  It seems like there should be a server id displayed on the page that asks for the existing license to be pasted in.
fields.summary: Installer doesn't present server id when you pick the option of using an existing license

fields.description:
If an user is cloning a managed repository while an user is also pushing some changes, the part of FishEye serving the requests can cause the cloning client to freeze.

This happens if the two requests (for the head refs and for the pack-file negotiation) for each push and pull are interleaved.

See attachement for an example: [^interleaving.jpg]

fields.description:
GitServlet has issues with ProcessUtils special treatment of processes on Windows platforms, so we've disabled it for the moment. The "special" treatment worked around some code page issues on Windows, but was failing for us. 

The javadoc on ExternalProcessImpl#createWinProcess goes into more detail:
{code}
/*
      * This method provides a workaround for a JVM bug on windows (see http://bugs.sun.com/bugdatabase/view_bug.do?bug_id=4947220). The bug
      * is that the Sun/Oracle JVM uses the (8 bit) OEM codepage for encoding commandline arguments that are passed to an external process.  Any
      * characters in a command line argument that can't be represented in the OEM codepage will be replaced by the '?' character, which will probably
      * cause the command that's being called to fail.
      *
      * A bit of background information is helpful to understand what's going on. Windows uses 2 code pages: the OEM code page and the ANSI code page
      * (or 'Windows code page'). The OEM code page is always limited to 8 bit character encodings, whereas some windows code pages are 8 bit and some
      * are larger. The OEM code page is typically used for console applications, whereas the windows code pages are used for native non-Unicode application
      * using a GUI on Windows systems.  The system-wide settings can be found in the windows registry:
      *
      *
      * More info about the history of OEM vs ANSI code pages: http://blogs.msdn.com/b/michkap/archive/2005/02/08/369197.aspx
      *
      * The workaround is to store the command-line arguments in environment variables and refer to the environment vars on the command line. Windows
      * cmd will expand the command line arguments without using to the OEM code page, which usually has more correlation with the locale of the
      * producer of the hardware (it's derived from the BIOS code page) than with the regional settings configured in Windows. The ANSI code page is derived from
      * the regional settings.
      *
      * When cmd expands the %JENV_XXX% vars on the command line it uses the ANSI code page instead of the OEM code page (or that is what testing
      * seems to indicate, can't find any definitive answer in the cmd docos). While this still isn't a true fix to the problem, for most situations this will be sufficient
      * as the user typically won't use characters that aren't defined for his locale. But then again, they might..
     */
    private Process createWinProcess(String[] cmdArray, String[] environment, File workingDir) throws IOException
{code}

fields.description:
FECRU-1033 solved the lines of code calculation issue for diffs with windows EOL characters, but the diff that is indexed will be truncated.

Basically, when a new line is encountered that does not start with '+' or '-', the current section is terminated and the remainder is ignored. The LoC is now correct, because we base it on the unified diff header for the section.
fields.summary: Diff text indexing is incomplete for diffs with windows eol characters for Git and Mercurial

fields.description:
When we get the diff using SVNClient.diff(...), the diff for lines with non-ascii characters appears to be truncated by the svnkit implementation. For instance, when getting the diffs for revision 68 in the checkstyle SVN repository:

svn diff -r 67:68 file:///Users/mheemskerk/work/repo/svn/checkstyle/trunk/checkstyle/src/tests/com/puppycrawl/tools/checkstyle@68  | less

the svnkit implementation that we use from FishEye returns:

{code}
+/**
+ * Tests for anonymous inner types
+ * @author Lars K�+ **/
{code}

but the svn commandline returns:

{code}
+/**
+ * Tests for anonymous inner types
+ * @author Lars K<FC>hne
+ **/
{code}

The truncation unfortunately also removes the EOL from the line in question, and the result is that in FishEye misses the end of the diff section. This results in wrong diff hunks for the file in question (and potentially next files in the same diff).

The relevant bit of source: https://extranet.atlassian.com/crucible/browse/FE-hg/src/java/com/cenqua/fisheye/svn/diff/SvnDiffParser.java?r=ee09ae822322549c4496d15e8e73d32eace572fe#to277
fields.summary: Subversion: truncated line in diff causes blame calculation errors

fields.description:
On the file history page, we place a {{HEAD}} marker for each file revision that is a {{HEAD}} anywhere in the repository. We should only show the markers for revisions which are head on the current branch.

Alternatively, we can show the {{HEAD}} marker as we do now if we can create an efficient manner of determining _which_ branches the file revisions are head on.

fields.description:
We recently converted from using SVN to Git with FishEye, and while overall we're really loving it - one of the "features" we've lost is the ability to see "relative age" when looking at the source view in FishEye.  I never really noticed its value until we moved, and now when looking at the source view, the Revision column (which is a Git short-sha), has less value.  With SVN i could use that to have a sense of how old some code was (cause i had a rough mental model of how our source repository rev numbers have increased over time).

The feature i'd like is to be able to add an "Age" column to the source view.  That would tell me a basic relative age of code i'm looking at; ie: 2 yrs ago.  I've seen this content when clicking on a commit link, so its information you have, but losing sequential revisions has suddenly made this much more important on the source view for us.
fields.summary: Add Age column to the source view

fields.description:
When a directory is moved or renamed, FishEye still shows the files contained in that directory (and subdirectories) at their old path. 

The problem is that FishEye indexes the repository by scanning for 'checkin' events and when a directory is renamed or moved, no events are generated for the elements contained in the affected directory. 

Any modifications to the moved items will be picked up by FishEye and will be indexed at the 'correct' path. However, the items at the old path will not be marked as deleted and FishEye will still show a file at the old path.
fields.summary: ClearCase: FishEye shows files at their old path after renaming or moving the directory that contains the files

fields.description:
When rendering the source of a file in the 'View source' page, the blame for a file takes precedence over the contents of the file. If the blame is incorrect or incomplete, the result is that only the parts of the file for which blame exists are rendered.

This should be switched around; the file contents should take precedence over the blame (as is the case in the diff view).

fields.description:
The linking between JIRA issue and Fisheye changeset is automatically created from commit message but where the commit message doesn't contains issue name and can't be changed (never change public history in Git!), there is no way to link the issue and the changeset...

Add a "link to changeset" in source tab of issues or a "link to issue" in changeset view would be very nice.
fields.summary: Add possibility to manually link a JIRA issue to a Fisheye changeset

fields.description:
Currently we define the 'default' branch in subversion as default. This is used in the branch selector as well as the commit graph.

Currently this ignores the configured name of the 'trunk-like' branch in the symbolic rules in the admin. It also doesn't play nicely with multi-project repository. For instance when you select 'trunk' in the branch selector, it will show you trunk for all projects.

Ideally it should support multi-trunk repositories but at the very least support unconventionally named trunk-like branches.
fields.summary: The 'Default Branch' should match what is configured in the Subversion symbolic structure rules and not just be trunk

fields.description:
EyeQL currently has many flaws in its implementation leading to poor response times, particularly with the JIRA FishEye plugin
* Searches are either done only against Infdb and sometimes are a join between infdb and lucene
* Sorts are done in memory
* Lucene queries are done against a changeset index, then split into file revisions, only to be aggregated again
* Many queries could be serviced purely by lucene due to stored data
* file revisions are eagerly loaded for every matching file revision, regardless of whether all fields are required of not

*Short term solution*
Create a separate API to service the JIRA FishEye Plugins needs, optimising the searches as best they can.

*Long term solution*
Fix EyeQL to:
* Allow searching for changesets, not just file revision
* Do a lucene first query, lazily fetching file revisions or changeset data from infdb
* use lucene for sorting results where possible
fields.summary: Slow response times in the JIRA FishEye Plugin caused by EyeQL suffering from performance issues

fields.description:
When indexing ClearCase repositories, FishEye retrieves the VOB history using lshistory. When an indexing start date is set in the FishEye configuration, that date is used as a -since argument to lshistory. When no indexing start date is set, FishEye uses the VOB creation date.

For VOBs created with clearfsimport this leads to issues, because clearfsimport conserves the creation date of the files that are imported. As a result the mkelem and checkin operations in the ClearCase history are dated before the VOB creation date and as a result, these files are not indexed by FishEye.

A workaround until this issue is fixed is to specify an indexing start date that is far in the past.
fields.summary: ClearCase: no files are indexed for an imported repository (using clearfsimport)

fields.description:
Hello, 

I've just installed FishEye 2.6.3, and my instance is up and running.

I don't have any Application Links configured yet in FishEye, and I'm trying to open the *Configure Application Links* screen for the very first time to create an Application Link to JIRA.

However, when I open the screen, a spinning icon is displayed forever with the message {{"Loading list of Application Links...."}}.

This problem happens on Internet Explorer 9 (I haven't tested with previous versions).
I've tried to reproduce the problem with Mozilla Firefox 5.0 and Google Chrome 13.0, but I was unable to, so the problem is browser related, specific to Internet Explorer.

Please see the images attached.
fields.summary: Configure Application Links screen showing spinning icon forever on Internet Explorer 9
